title: How to be 100% sure that my ebook has no typos before launching it - Quora

response.answer_text: You can’t. Look, in the most professional and conventional of publishing methods, a manuscript is seen by an agent, who reads it, makes suggestions, and flags any obvious errors. It’s submitted to publishing house, where at least one editor reads it, and if it’s really being considered, probably gives it to someone else to read as well. They discuss it, and also mark any obvious errors. After the book is acquired by the house, it will go through a story edit, a line edit, and proof and copy edits. After each pass, it will go back to the writer, who has an opportunity to clean it up. Next, it will go to a type setter, or the modern equivalent. There are more opportunities to clean it up, although technology has some new and interesting ways of introducing fascinating errors at that point. Next, without going into details, it becomes a book. Before it’s ready to be sold, copy and marketing and rights and maybe even art has read it, and at each point, they’ve had the opportunity to point out that there’s a spelling error on page 23. Now, this is with the most professional, most robust publishing process, a house that employs many people for the express purpose of getting everything right. Even with a book that is published by, for instance Random House, there will still be the odd typo or error. With a self-published e-book, you are dependent on yourself and a spell check to get everything right, and that spell check can change many things to words that are spelled correctly, but are the wrong word entirely. As an example, a rather famous writer at one point had a book with the phrase “My customers are always right,” but due to the wrong spelling, it was automatically changed to “My costumers are always right,” which is not the same thing at all. So, if you are self-publishing an e-book, your goal is to minimize any errors so that your text is not riddled with them, and they are not a distraction from what you have written. Go over that manuscript at least 3–4 times, always with time in between, and pay a professional to have a go at your manuscript as well. That’s your best bet.

Heh heh heh. You can’t ever be 100% sure, and I speak as someone who publishes books for a living. This is maddening, given that we devote a massive amount of time and effort to cleaning up manuscripts. Editors, copyeditors and proofreaders go through the manuscripts, layouts, and plotters multiple times hunting typos. The standard you want to hit is 100% clean, but you won’t hit that all the time, and every big publisher - even ones where there’s a whole department for cleaning up books - has a reprint correction book. The more hours and eyeballs you put in, the cleaner books get. If you’re going straight from manuscript to ebook you do at least remove the big-publishing hurdle where the ebook file is generated from the print PDF, and so the typesetting has had a chance to introduce typos. But if you want a good confidence that your ebook is clean, you’ll need to do the same kind of big-publishing process. In this case - if what you want is to kill typos, and not necessarily bad grammar or flat characters etc - then you need a professional proofread from a reputable freelance proofreader. In the UK this costs about 20 quid an hour, and for a novel you could be looking at ten hours or so. If you get that done and take in the proofread correctly (amending the manuscript in line with the proofreader’s markup) you should be up near a trade-published standard from that point of view.

Run it through Word's spell check first. It's very aggressive at catching all kinds of stuff.Make multiple passes, switching up the way you review your book each time, change the font and font size, print it out, review on a device, mix up the order of the chapters. etc. I catch the most non-obvious mistakes by using a text to voice utility to read my book aloud while I follow along on the screen. This is because the computer reads what is there while the human eye often sees what it thinks should be there.Get it as good as you can, thenTurn it over to a committee of nit pickers, as many different eyes as you can get. This is because different people notice different things.Now you're going to ask why you can't skip straight to #4. There is a thing I call error fatigue. Even the best proof reader will start skimming over errors if there are too many of them. They becone desensitized and stop seeing them. 5. Accept that typos are like cockroaches. They breed in the dark and it's doubtful that you'll squash all of them. Even bestselling authors from major publishing houses wind up with an error or two in their books. Thankfully, it is a simple matter to correct a self-published book — unlike trad books, where post publication revisions can't happen. Embrace those readers who point out your errors and use them to improve your books.

If only it was possible to do this! There are publishers with entire departments devoted to catching typographical errors and misprints, but even they can miss a "too" that should have been a "to." The best way to guard against typos is to read, reread, and reread again, employing a fresh pair of eyes each time. If you are the only person who can read your work, try reading the text backward (i.e., start at the very last page and work your way back one sentence at a time) or change the font size or color. If you can change perspectives, errors will become more obvious. That being said, you'll be much better off getting someone else to read the text, as other readers will not skim over the parts you've read a thousand times before. They will be reading it with a fresh perspective. If possible, look for a professional proofreader or proofreading service that will provide you with both a "tracked" copy of your work (showing every correction made and why) along with a "clean" copy (showing no markup, only the finished corrected text). Then, compare your original book with the two copies so you can see how your text changed. This will give you a new perspective, too, and you'll benefit from one other thing that helps prevent typos: experience working with them. Happy revising!

response.answer_text: Thanks for your request Hollie. I can’t add much more than Emil’s comprehensive reply! Unfortunately, you can never be 100% sure that your book has no typos in it. Even the biggest name publishers send books to print with what seems like glaring typos in them. And that’s despite having multiple experienced proofreaders check each book. Historically, books have always had typos in them, and it used to be part of the process that readers used to submit errata. That said, of course you want to do as much as possible to reduce typos. So when the book is in its final format (i.e. has been formatted and designed), then check everything has been formatted correctly and no content is missing or has been duplicated. Then hire an experienced proofreader who has great feedback to check the book in its final format, and one who has knowledge of your particular language and type of language (such as British English, American English). If you have an editor, my advice is to hire a separate proofreader. This is because the person looking for typos and formatting errors shouldn’t be familiar with the content. Ideally, have multiple pairs of eyes check the book to eliminate as many errors as possible. And ask them to check it multiple times. The more checking, the less errors.

response.answer_text: You can never be sure there are no errors in anything you create. However, the best way to minimize errors in your book is to get a good editor to review it. You can ask your editor to arrange for the services of necessary specialists such as proofreaders. If you can’t afford services of a professional editor, you can try haggling. Don’t forget, though — the editor has to pay bills, too. Once your manuscript has been turned into a publication-ready document, you and your editor go over it again. They you release your book, and wait for your readers to tell you about the stuff you missed. If you’re very lucky, there won’t be anything. Don’t count on being that lucky, because it’s rare. Good luck!
You can never be 100% sure. Just do your best.

Change the format. When you first write something your brain remembers what you meant to put, which makes it hard to spot your own errors, sometimes for months. But changing the font or pasting the whole thing into an email tricks your eyes into seeing what’s really there.

It’s nigh on impossible to proof your own work, so it takes other eyes to do it. Even then, there’s no guarantee that it’ll be 100%. Get it as good as you can and then go for it; otherwise, you’ll fret and worry about it and it’ll prevent you from moving forward, and that’s ridiculous.
There will be a typo. It’s a law of the universe. If a typo didn’t exist, like Schrodinger’s cat, it will exist but only when you’re not looking at it. Or it might not. That’s the nature of typos.
Use the Grammarly online application (premium, not the free version) to spell and grammar check your book. Free version is good, but premium version well worth the price.

Proof read a hard copy. Do not trust spell check. You will not catch everything. Or hire a proofreader to do it. I, for example, often drop the second quote mark in dialogue, because I learned writing screenplays. I miss it all the time.

You really can’t. You can run spell check. You can have it proof read - preferably by people with a good grasp of spelling, usage and a very good vocabulary. . You can do both. You can do both multiple times. But occasional errors always seem to creep through.
